content.div:
You could look at it as yet another TV singing competition. Us, we like to think of it as an excuse for a new Kelly Clarkson (and Robin Thicke and Jennifer Nettles and Lionel Richie) concert every week.

Those four pop stars are joining the just announced ABC series, Duets, a reality competition in no way inspired by the Gwyneth Paltrow/Huey Lewis movie of the same name (but could still produce yet another cover of "Cruisin") that's set to debut sometime this summer. And though contestants will ultimately be vying for the typical reality-show prize (in this case, a recording contract from Disney's Hollywood Records), the program is being sold as something warmer and fuzzier and anti-snarkier than its competition.

Never mind their qualifications, the star panel won't be judging anyone. (Let he who's never been pitchy cast the first zinger, dawg.) Instead, Clarkson, Thicke, Richie and Sugarland singer Nettles will scout contestants from around the U.S., then act as their mentors. Each week, they'll coach two singers toward a live TV duet. By the end of each episode, a winner will be declared -- thus landing that aforementioned recording contract. (As for the rest, they can presumably go back to whatever regional theatre production of Rent they came from, and tell their friends about that one time they sang "Dancing on the Ceiling" on TV.)

Though a premiere date hasn't been set, it seems Duets will be joining a TV schedule already packed tighter than a football stadium on Idol audition day with singing competitions: there's American Idol, The X Factor, America's Got Talent, a just-announced Queen Latifah project, The Voice (which has recently featured three of Duets' star mentors: Clarkson, Richie and Thicke). And then there's the history of "duet" programs that have gone -- and failed -- before, including Simon Cowell's Celebrity Duets, and CMT's Can You Duet?.

In a just-released promo video for the show, Duets' stars insist -- as one does in a promo video -- that their program will shine like the special diamond it is.

"What first drew me to the whole idea of the show Duets was the fact that it was kinda completely different," Clarkson says in the clip, "and a sense that we would actually get to collaborate with the artist that we choose. And they don't audition like a normal process, so I think it's really cool that we get to go find the talent that we really believe in and we get to perform with them, and at the same time be able to help mold someone into whatever they want to do with their career."

Watch the sneak peek below:

leahc@dose.ca
